botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in full sun with fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil. For best flowering apply a balanced fertiliser and mulch in late winter or early spring - see rose cultivation. Tolerant of poor soil and shade. Can be trained as a climber or pillar rose
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by hardwood cuttings in autumn or by chip budding in summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Pruning group 21 (roses). Do not prune after flowering if hips are required
how_to_grow.pests: May be attacked by rose aphid, rose leafhopper, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose sawfly, rose leaf-rolling sawfly, leaf cutting bees, rabbits and deer
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by black spot, rose rust and rose powdery mildew
